Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Creating Materials via Active Self-Assembly Driven by Biomolecular Motors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Career award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Florida is to support studies in understanding the crucial first steps towards assembling strained and non-equilibrium structures which significantly expand the accessible design space in nanotechnology. The objective of the program is to show that the current boundaries of self-assemblies can be dramatically expanded by biomolecular motors. Specifically, the proposed studies will be shown that biomolecular motors can: (1) accelerate self-assembly; (2) generate non-equilibrium structures; (3) impose an assembly hierarchy; (4) assemble macroscopic structures from nanoscale building blocks; and (5) integrate synthetic building blocks. To this end, the project utilizes a carefully crafted combination of experiments, theory, and computer simulations to generate insights into the dynamics of a model system, which is based on functionalized microtubules gliding and self assembling on kinesin motor-coated surfaces. Using taxol-stabilized and biotinylated microtubules as building blocks ranging in size from 1 micrometer to 50 micrometer in length will be prepared. The assembly of biotinylated microtubules partially covered with streptavidin will be conducted on kinesin-coated and lipid layer-coated surfaces to compare motor-driven and diffusion-driven assemblies respectively. The goal of the program is to formulate the rules governing these "activated" self-assembly processes. These insights will impact the synthesis of nanostructures with applications in molecular electronics and adaptive materials, and will also dramatically further our understanding of the role of biomolecular motors in the assembly of biological materials. By dissecting the processes of hierarchical assembly and the integration of synthetic building blocks, it would be possible that a large number of independent transporters in combination with a basic set of interaction rules can assemble complex structures with sizes orders of magnitude larger than the individual transporter. This represents a biomimetic approach to the rapid assembly of nanoscale building blocks into complex nano- and mesoscale structures, which marries self-assembly principles with the controlled generation of molecular forces by nanomachines. The nanomachines of choice are biomolecular motors, which can efficiently convert chemical energy into mechanical work. A cellular automaton-based approach will be used to model the dynamics of the system, and assemble a software package to provide a general modeling tool for molecular motor-based self-assembly.

The research project spans the interface between the life sciences and engineering, drawing inspirations and materials from biology and quantitative approaches and applications from engineering. Two innovative activities are proposed to integrate research and teaching: (1) Development of a software program in collaborative with computer scientists to visualize thermal motion in experiments that are being developed, and this visualization is to provide an improved view into the nanoworld. In addition to visualizing the systems, the software will build a game, which lets the player act in a nanoworld buffeted by thermal motion; and (2) Interdisciplinary training of undergraduate students through international collaborations and interactions, which will be expanded on existing collaborations of the PI through a program for international research experiences for undergraduate students at University of Florida in Germany, Switzerland, Great Britain and Japan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project has focused on the study of active self-assembly. While chemical reactions rely on diffusion to assembly molecules, and assembly processes in factories rely on humans and robots, active self-assembly processes are of particular use for microscopic objects. Active self-assembly has always been used by nature to organize the structures in cells, but only recently have we been able to study active self-assembly processes as engineers in experiments outside the cell. The key ingredient, justifying the adjective “active”, are biomolecular motors which can propel building blocks and exert forces to rapidly assemble them into larger structures. Using experiments, calculations and simulations, we studied the assembly of microtubule filaments into larger structures by kinesin motors. These efforts have resulted in a better understanding of what determines the outcome of the assembly process and what the advantages over traditional manufacturing methods are. These insights will be of use as technology advances to build chips and devices not only at the microscale but even at the nanoscale. In addition, insights into the workings of polymer coatings which prevent the attachment of proteins and bacteria to surfaces – an issue of central importance in the suppression of implant-related infections, for example – have been obtained. Our work to understand how molecules move and assemble into larger structures has also enabled us to better model the functioning of enzyme complexes which convert chemicals in multistep reactions. Such enzyme complexes can generate pharmaceuticals and biofuels, and a detailed understanding of their functioning facilitates their engineering.

Seven graduate students have contributed to the project (3 female, 2 minority) and three PhD degrees have already been awarded. An example of their success is the first place in the oral presentation competition at the 36th Annual National Society of Black Engineers Conference, Toronto, Canada (4/1/2010) for Dr. Jasmine Davenport-Crenshaw’s presentation: “Lattice Simulations of Microtubule “Nanospool” Formation Dynamics”. Dr. Davenport-Crenshaw is now a Materials Scientist at the Department of Defense, Dr. Yolaine Jeune-Smith is a postdoctoral fellow at the Moffitt Cancer Center, and Dr. Ashutosh Agarwal just accepted a faculty position at the University of Miami.

Eighteen undergraduate researchers have been involved in the laboratory and during summer research experiences at national and international partner laboratories, for example at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Cell Biology and Genetics in Dresden, Germany and the Japan Advanced Institute for Science and Technology in Kanazawa, Japan. Teams of undergraduate and high school students working in our laboratory have participated in the 2011, 2012, and 2013 BIOMOD International Biomolecular Design Competitions organized by the Wyss Institute at Harvard University. Other outreach activities have targeted high school and elementary school students. The research results of this project have been incorporated into two new graduate courses taught by the PI.

The project has also led to a strengthening of ties with international researchers. Dr. Takahiro Nitta and Dr. Yuichi Hiratsuka have spent sabbaticals at the Hess laboratory and hosted undergraduate researchers at their facilities in Japan. Interactions with Prof. Stefan Diez from the Technical University Dresden in Germany led to the selection of our laboratory as a partner laboratory of the Dresden International Graduate School for Biomedicine and Bioengineering.

In summary, this CAREER award has played the intended role of anchoring the research efforts of the Hess laboratory and of stimulating a wide range of education activities.
